6-Mate English
From BBC Learning English
Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English
speaker: Dan

text: the program where we bring you an interesting topic and six items of vocabulary.
I'm Dan and today we're talking about...
Sying. I'm Catherine.
Now, was that a real sigh or just one to demonstrate the meaning?
speaker: Dan

text: That one was just for educational purposes, of course, Dan.
We’ll be looking at why we sigh, and learn how sighing keeps us alive
speaker: Dan

text: Yes, very interesting. And it's not just humans that sigh, is it Dan?
Indeed, most mammals sigh. And that brings me to today’s question
speaker: Dan

text: How many times does a mouse sigh in an hour on average?
Is it a twice, b 10 times or c 40 times?
I'm going to say the poor little thing was sigh about 40 times an hour.
Okay, let's find out if you'll write later on in the program.
Now, what is a sigh exactly?
speaker: Catherine

text: Let's hear from Dr. Lin Barker, a cognitive neuroscientist from Sheffield-Hallum University in the UK.
It's a typically cardio respiratory kind of resetting mechanism
and most mammals will engage in sying of some kind.
Because people who don't sigh will eventually die, but it is a survival mechanism.
So, sying keeps us alive.
Dr Barker called it a survival mechanism.
speaker: Catherine

text: To survive means to continue living, especially in difficult circumstances.
A mechanism here means a system of behaviour.
So, a survival mechanism is something the body does automatically in order to survive.
speaker: survival mechanismsurvival mechanism

text: But, Dan, why is sying a survival mechanism?
It's because sying can reset the lungs.
To reset is to return something to its original settings.
We often use this verb when talking about technology.
You can reset a computer or a phone.
Okay, that's fine, but how does a sigh reset the lungs?
Well, scientists from UCLA, that's the University of California, Los Angeles,
speaker: reset

text: found that a sigh is a special kind of very deep breath
that keeps the tiny sacks of air in our lungs,
called alveoli, working properly.
And without sying, these alveoli would collapse and we would die.
We need the alveoli to transfer oxygen from our lungs to our blood.
speaker: Catherine

text: Thankfully, we don't have to think about this need to reset our lungs.
Sying is in fact a reflex.
Boo!
speaker: Catherine

text: Ha!
speaker: Catherine

text: Ha!
speaker: reflex

text: Ha!
speaker: breathe a sigh of relief

text: There you jumped and that was a fabulous reflex, Dan.
It's something our bodies do without thinking.
Something you do unconsciously or automatically.
I meant, ah, like a man.
Thank you for that, Catherine.
You’re welcome.
speaker: Catherine

text: Do you sigh a lot?
Well, I sigh when I'm tired and I sigh when I'm relieved.
I breathe a sigh of relief.
To breathe a sigh of relief, that's a great expression.
It means what you think it means to sigh when you feel good
that something bad has not happened.
But it's often used metaphorically.
It relates more to the feeling of relief than the act of sying.
That’s right.
speaker: breathed a sigh of relief

text: Now, I breathed a sigh of relief when I found my mobile phone the other day.
I thought I'd lost it.
It was new.
I was so pleased when I found it.
What about you, Dan?
I tend to sigh to show frustration
and sometimes resignation.
No, frustration is what we feel when things aren't going well,
when things are annoying us and they don't work,
speaker: frustrationfrustrating

text: when things are frustrating.
And resignation is what we feel when we finally accept
that something bad has happened, that we can't change.
We feel resigned to something.
So, relief, resignation, frustration, resetting our lungs.
speaker: Catherine

text: It sounds like we humans never stop sying.
Well, actually, we humans sigh on average 12 times an hour.
But what about mice?
Well, I said, I reckon they sigh about 40 times an hour
speaker: Catherine

text: Well, in fact, it is 40 times an hour.
The hearts of mice beat faster,
so they need to regulate their lungs more than humans.
Let’s review today’s vocabulary.
speaker: Catherine

text: We had the phrase survival mechanism,
something we do without thinking that keeps us alive.
We often use this phrase
speaker: Catherine

text: and the related phrase defense mechanism
when talking about what people do to cope with difficulties in life.
Next, we had reset.
You can reset a computer or a machine to make it work again.
This usually means switching it off and on again.
And you can reset a password
speaker: Catherine

text: This is a little bit different.
It means to set or choose a new password.
We also had the word reflex.
This is a physical action or reaction
that you can't control.
For example, Catherine?
Yes, Dan.
There, you closed your eyes. Another reflex
speaker: Catherine

text: And we had to breathe a sigh of relief,
Which means to feel better after something bad doesn’t happen
speaker: tobreathe a sigh to relief

text: I breathe a sigh of relief when my friend recovered from her illness.
But we sigh for other reasons too.
Two useful sying words were frustration and resignation.
Frustration is the state of being frustrated.
speaker: Frustrationfrustratedfrustratingfrustrating

text: We can say something is frustrating.
It's frustrating when the boss doesn't listen to me.
But let's say you move beyond feeling frustrated
and start feeling resigned.
Yeah,
speaker: resign

text: And that would be when I finally accept the boss will never listen to me.
And that's when I'll resign.
To resign also means to voluntarily leave a job.
Please, Catherine, tell me that's just another vocabulary example.
Of course it is, Dan. I love my job!
speaker: Catherine

text: You.
speaker: Catherine

text: I only have a sigh about what?
12 times an hour?
Which is perfectly average.
